text: Patient: Well, we sold the house. Doctor: Okay. Congratulations. I think. (Laughs) Patient: Sold the house and we haven’t… Family Member: We’re living at my dad’s without a stove and refrigerator so we’re eating out all the time. Doctor: That’s it. I’m going to get you people straight now. Right here. Doctor: You’re giving me heartburn. You are. Patient: Yeah, well, this is true. Eating out. Family Member: Well there’s good choices you can make. Doctor: Yeah. (Laughs) Patient: You know and a lot more bad ones. Doctor: That is true. Huh, this makes a lot of sense now. Okay. And when do we expect to leave your dad’s house? Patient: I think we’re supposed to be getting the keys to the house we’re purchasing next week. Doctor: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing… Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations.

text: Patient: I can’t cough. Doctor: No, no I’m not uh doing it to hurt you. Patient: Oooh. (inaudible) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It would be sore and like I told the doctor. Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: I have never, in twenty something years man, I could drink a beer, I have, I have been with my family on holidays and drunk liquor Hennesy like going crazy and I’d never get one to throw up or got sick or something like that. I just went to sleep, but now I I I have… Doctor: Now what happens when you drink? Patient: I throwed up three times man. And I haven’t told and I don’t know if it was blood because I’ve been probably because the light was kind of dim, but it was like red and then it could have been the food I was eating. Doctor: When did you throw up? Patient: About, about maybe uh the chemo now I have diarrhea like two three weeks after. Doctor: Right. When did you throw up is what I’m asking. Patient: Same day I had chemo.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but it can be effective against the cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I personally tend to use chemotherapy later than most of the people. Uh, and part of the reason for that is because we have a lot of trials which, you know, we believe in, of course, because they’re our studies. And we have best of interest in them. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we have laboratory research on those things, so we are excited, you know – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - to go to humans, human trials, but, uh, unless, unless your pain is getting substantially worse, in which case I would strongly encourage you to do the chemo, because that’s going to work the fastest. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. I’m gonna put the prescription for the enzalutamide in our pharmacy, and they’re gonna do all the work behind the scenes to find out how much it’s gonna cost ya. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Put in the grants and all that other stuff for ya, so that we can get it. Once we know it’s a go, that’s when R_ and I will be back in touch about that. Okay? But you can always back out and say, “This doesn’t make sense. I’m not ready. He’s crazy. We’re not going back to Baltimore.” All of that. Okay? Something bad could happen. You could get in a lot of pain, and they got to treat you right then and there, and this will, will slip past you. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But I hope that doesn’t happen. Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for – Doctor: Yeah, I mean other diseases we’ve had people who, uh, their cancer doesn’t come back. Okay? But we haven’t seen that in prostate cancer. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I mean, I didn’t even have a prostate when I got it. How did that happen? Family Member: I don’t think they always got it all out of your lymph nodes when they first harvested it. Doctor: Yeah. It had to be there before they did the surgery.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him.

text: Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. Family Member 1: When will you know that? Doctor: Yeah, so this is where it gets complicated. I'm gonna have my research nurse M_____ come in, it's always the devils in the details. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: What's tight about this and what's goofy about it and we've already shared this with a company is that they almost want to be like, okay, we know everything about you. And then two weeks later, you have to start. So there's a time thing that's so compressed, that I even fear that you might even, you know, need another CAT scan, because they only want everything done in a two week window. So if that's the case, obviously, she'll time it out. But I defer to the research team to make sure that that's done correctly. And I've learned over the years to basically zip it because I say something they're like, “Yeah, no, you just botched up that schedule.” So I just stay out of it and let Melanie take over. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But most of the things we'll be measuring will be that area by your bladder that was squishing the kidney. So that's a big spot that we really want to keep an eye on. Then of course, bone stuff, but that's an area and you’d want to know that this stuff is shrinking. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Chemo is chemo. So, you know, like we talked about last time, whether it's the pill version or the IV, we always worry about hair loss, you know, tiredness, how it affects your liver numbers, that's measured by blood. We always worry about your white cells, red cells, platelets- Patient: Right, right. Doctor: -you know, all the words that make you you. But that's why you're here getting, you know= Family Member 1: Monitored.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
